title: Routing (MapGet, MapPost, MapPut, MapDelete)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine a file cabinet with different actions:
• READ a file (GET) - Just look, don't change
• CREATE new file (POST) - Add new document
• UPDATE existing file (PUT) - Replace entire file
• DELETE file (DELETE) - Remove it

These are HTTP METHODS (or VERBS)! Each has a purpose:

GET = Read data (no changes)
POST = Create new resource
PUT = Update existing resource (full update)
DELETE = Remove resource
PATCH = Partial update (advanced)

REST API pattern:
• GET /api/products - List all
• GET /api/products/5 - Get one
• POST /api/products - Create new
• PUT /api/products/5 - Update
• DELETE /api/products/5 - Delete

ASP.NET Core mapping:
• app.MapGet() - GET requests
• app.MapPost() - POST requests
• app.MapPut() - PUT requests
• app.MapDelete() - DELETE requests

Think: Different HTTP methods = Different actions on same resource!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Handles POST requests (create). Handler receives request body as parameter. ASP.NET Core auto-deserializes JSON to object!
Returns 201 Created status. First param is URL of new resource. Second is the created object. Standard for POST!
Handles PUT requests (update). Typically receives ID in route and updated object in body: (int id, Product product) => ...
Returns 204 No Content. Common for DELETE - operation succeeded but no data to return.

challenge.instructions:
Build a complete CRUD API for Tasks!

1. Create 'TaskItem' class:
   - int Id
   - string Title
   - string Description
   - bool IsCompleted

2. Create in-memory list with 2 initial tasks

3. Implement ALL CRUD operations:
   - GET /api/tasks - Return all tasks
   - GET /api/tasks/{id} - Return single task
   - POST /api/tasks - Create new task (auto-assign ID)
   - PUT /api/tasks/{id} - Update task
   - DELETE /api/tasks/{id} - Delete task

4. For POST: use nextId counter for auto-incrementing IDs

5. Print available endpoints when API starts
challenge.hint: MapPost: 'app.MapPost(route, (Object obj) => ...)'. Assign ID before adding! MapPut: update properties one by one. MapDelete: .Remove() from list. Return proper Results: Created, Ok, NoContent, NotFound.
commonStickingPoints: Not assigning ID in POST: Client shouldn't provide ID for new items! Server assigns it: 'task.Id = nextId++'. Then add to list. ID assignment is server's job!
Modifying wrong object in PUT: Don't modify 'updatedTask' parameter! Find existing item in list, then update ITS properties. Otherwise changes aren't persisted.
Forgetting to remove in DELETE: Must call 'list.Remove(item)'! Just returning NoContent() doesn't delete it. Actually remove from collection!
Using same route for different methods: Same route with different methods is FINE! GET /api/tasks and POST /api/tasks are different endpoints. Method matters, not just URL!
